section.hand:
To M
r
Secretary Oc
t
10. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 10 Octo
b
To M
r
Secretary
It may please yo
r
H.
e messenge
r
t
I sent to
Embden
about the
motion of
Groenighen
is newly retourned & hath brought mee that
answere wh
r
of I send yo
r
hono
r
e coppy heerinclozed as also of
mine owne unto him, & of
e other w
ch
I writt at large & w
th
out
su
scription to be indorsed to any such of
e Towne, or oth
r
wise as hee
should fynde most expedi
e
t wh
r
of in my form
r
l
re
s I have written
to yo
r
Hono
r
. The messenger taking
Frise
his waie hath had some
conference w
th
e
p
r
sident of Aisma
who signified unto him that hee
had written of this matt
r
long since unto yo
w
& to
Mons
r
Sonoye
fr
o
whom I do not dout but yo
w
have had as ample informa
o
n, as
is requesyt. The minist
r
of Embden a man knowen to
M
r
Gilpin
& commonly reputed a
son of good judgement hath also writt
e
very effectually to
e same effect as
e Burgherm
r
& affirmeth
that
e interprise for c
r
taine is both easy & assured, requiring
nothing so much as secrecy & speed. I doo commonly see there in this
country very soone
swaded to build great assurance uppon
slender likelihods, howbeit in
is cause I finde a gen
r
all
concurrence of all theyr opinions w
th
wh
o
I have conferred
albeit heth
r
to I have not im
ted any
te of my dealing w
th
any
of
e
Counsell
or of
e
States
attending alwaies yf it be a
matter
t
hir
Ma
ty
will embrace such furder direction as yo
r
hono
r
shall send. After
e de
ture of those deputies that ar
sent from hence ynto
Fraunce,
the gen
r
all states sent theyr
Secretary to communicat privately theyr Instructions unto mee.
wherin they have vouchsafed to acquaint mee furder then in theyr
oth
r
actions heertofor, w
ch
I do interpret as doon for
t
they wold
seeme, at least in shew to affect a good correspondence. Because
I see but littell matter of principall consydera
o
n I wold not
be so curious as to crave a coppy, but being mindefull of
e
principall points I thought to im
te them to yo
r
H. In their
fyrst accesse to
e
King
they ar willed after many complement
of thank
for his infinite travailles in defence of the common cause
w
th
e daily dange
r
of his owne
son to congratulate his
fortunate conjunction w
th
e late
King
& his Lawfull succession
since to
e Crowne & to wishe him th
r
in all continuance of prosperity
they ar also to relate
e p
nt
state of theyr affaires & to
reco
m
end th
e
to
e K to request a good acceptation of that w
ch
they have lately accorded up
o
e proposition of
Mons
r
de la
Thuillerie
& to offer what furder assistance theyr feeble state will
affoord, acknowledging
e [weale] & good of these contreys to defend
chiefly upon
e happy event of
e Ks affayres. They shall also
make report of that w
ch
they have negotiated in
Germany
w
th
e
princes of
e Empire to induce th
e
to restrict alliance &
association against
e holy league.
In theyr second audience for w
ch
they ar to make petition in regard
of theyr
[ticular] causes they shalbe come [suters] that theyr contracts
made heertofor between
e inhabitant
of France & these contreys
fol.144v
touching
e entercourse of traffique may be held still for
good & confirmed namely
e priviledges graunted by
Lo uis
the XI
to
e inhabitant
of
Braband
Flanders
Holl
a
d
&
Zel
a
d
& all arrest
& edictes published to
e contrary to bee
repealed. They are furder to give up a note unto
e King
of c
r
tain unjust reprisales that have bin graunted forth against
the inhabitant
of these countreys. Are also to sollicit
t
the shippes of Brabant Flanders &
e Malc
o
tent
elswhere
may not be suffred to harbo
r
w
th
in any of theyr port
& havens
of
e Townes in
e Ks obeisance.
They shall declare w
th
as great efficacy as they can both to
e K &
e nobility w
th
him how impossible it is for him
if
e
K of Spaine
should gett
e upper hand in these contreys
to continuew quiet in his kingdome.
These articles were somewhat more amply sett dowen & there
were more in nomb
r
but rath
r
importing matt
r
of cowrse th
e
of
moment. Righte nowe I receaved adv
r
tisement fr
o
Si
r
Francis
Drake
Vere
&
e like is signifyed by
e Count [Ov
r
steyn]
to
e Counsell of
e 5
th
of this moneth o
r
forces m
r
ching toward
Berch
w
th
victuall & being come w
th
in a League of
e Towen
were by
e Ennemy who had newly renforced his troupes w
th
fresh
[succo
rs
] from
e quarters about
Huesden
being as yt was [.] [.]
about 3000 charged in
e reregard going out of a streight
passage. Howbeit S
r
Francis Vere w
th
e English companies und
r
his conduct w
ch
were in
t
place shewed so much vallew in making
resistance as
e common brute doth c
o
mend th
e
exceedingly & hee
him self waiteth
t
for the space of an hour [together] they fought most
fiercely at hard blowes drawe
e ennemy back 4 times, put
th
e
at last to flight 7 killed 600 up
o
e plate being Spaniard
& Albanois of
e bravest among th
e
& brought awaie 12 ensignes
and 250 horses. There were but few prisoners taken & it was
not yet knowen what principall
sons were slayne among them
neither is it c
r
tifyed whatt losse of men we sustayned it is onely
signifyed
t
43 english ar brought hurt into
Arnham.
After
e conflict
ey continued one theyr marche toward
e Towne of
Berch victualled yt made an honorable retrayt into
Rees
while they were in fight those of Berch issued forth & tooke
one of
e Ennemies sconses before the Towne where they killed
e most of
e souldiers & forced
e rest to drowen them selves
in
e river & in
e Bogges, wh
r
uppon
e Ennemy was m
r
vailously
freighted & abandoned all
e sconses th
r
about. This day we had
also letters of
e
Count Newenars
decease up
o
e accident
wherof I c
r
tifyed yo
r
H in my last.
And so for this tyme
I take my humble leave. Oc
t
10. 89 fr
o
e Haghe.
